Website content strategy: It’s not about you.

11 Jun 2011

We recently finished a content strategy session with Planet In Focus. We’re redesigning their site to serve their business goals. Strange as it may sound, it’s a new approach for them. And they’re not alone.

Over the last ten years, brands have been faced with a marketing challenge that never existed before: What content should my website have?

Most people’s knee jerk response to the question is: “All of it”. Then they set about a lengthy process of organizing everything they could say about themselves. This approach offers a few challenges off the bat:

  • It’s a lot of work, and can often bog down or be an unbearable burden on a web project. Especially since people tend to leave it until the end.
  • It can polarize stakeholders who all want to see their piece reflected on the home page
  • It doesn’t leverage the web’s key benefits over printâ€“the ability to assess people’s interest level in your content, earning the interest of more qualified leads, relevance in the eyes of search engines, etc

A brick and mortar analogy to this approach would be selling your house without ‘fluffing’ it. Even if you never baked a day in your life, it’s worthwhile to pop some apple turnovers in the oven when you’re having an open house.

The reason is that most people aren’t interested in you, they’re interested in how their association with you can help them fulfill their interests. If you can help them picture themselves baking away in their new home, all the better.

Developing web site content that matters to people means starting with why they’re coming. Who do you honestly expect to come to your site and what are they expecting to find there?

From there, you can cajole them gently down a path towards your goals.
